Another important fact admitted by Dr. Rush, is one furnished him by Dr. Otto: viz.—"In the autumn of the year
1798, it (a malignant remittent fever) prevailed upon the
shores of the Delaware, in Gloucester county, New Jersey.
A mild Remittent prevailed, at the same lime, on the high
grounds, a few miles from the river. During this time, the
Doctor observed, if a poison who bad taken the yellow fever

the same disease appeared, in several instances, in one or
more branches of that family: but where persons brought
the fever from the city, and went into a family on the high
grounds, where the mild remittents prevailed, there was not a
single instance of a yellow fever having been excited by them
in any of its members." Med. Repos. v. G, p. 1G0. This
